name: Case Briefs
description: A digest the recent developments and older â€œlandmarkâ€ cases involving Islamic law. Scholars of Islamic law review cases from countries all over the globe, over Islamâ€™s 1400-year history. The full text of the cases, and more, are all available on the SHARIAsource Portal.

name: Cases and Fatwās Roundup
description: Cases and FatwÄs Roundup: a list of court cases, decrees and other opinions relating to Islamic law issued by legal authorities, Islamic institutions, and jurists.

name: Courts & Canons
description: Courts&Canons (CnC) is a suite of AI and other data science tools that facilitate research and insights into Islamic law and the motivating values behind it, across space and time. These tools allow researchers to  organize and combine sources for legal canons, fatwÄs, and reports of early cases with key biographies of jurists and judges who produced them on a single online platform from all schools of Islamic law, with a focus on Islamâ€™s generative â€˜founding periodâ€™ (1stâ€“5th/7thâ€“11th centuries), and they also facilitate identifying and â€˜meme-mappingâ€™ canons, forging connections between canons and between other named entities (authors, titles, places), and collaborative research among scholars seeking to answer major questions in Islamic law and history.Â We experiment with ways in which the data science tools we are developing can aid in that research.

name: Lexicon
description: Something of a glossary, something of a thesaurus of the Islamic world. The Islamic Law Lexicon helps readers quickly digest key concepts in Islamic law. Our editors curate and simplify the core terms relevant to the study of Islamic law to offer straightforward (and varied) definitions. For more lengthy but equally accessible reviews of the scholarship behind the concepts, see the Scholarship in Plain English collection.

name: News mentions of Covid-19 and Islamic Law
description: A list of COVID-19-related developments in Muslim-majority countries and among Islamic communities from March 2020 through December 2022. Related to this particular roundup is our Mapping COVID-19 FatwÄs project, which compiles and discusses various Islamic legal opinions issued all across the globe on the pandemic and how Muslims ought to conduct themselves in the fight against it

name: Roundtable
description: A place where scholars gather around to discuss and debate new questions in Islamic law, virtually. For our series of Roundtables and Symposia, the Islamic Law Blog invites leading scholars and experts on Islamic law to debate new questions, cases, debates that arise all over the world. Their perspectives add nuanced views of multiple sides of the issues. Below are the roundtables we have hosted so far, in reverse chronological order: â€¢ 2022 Roundtable: The History of Islamic International Law (convened by Intisar Rabb & Umut Ã–zsu) Islamic Law Blog (Dec. 2022) [Foreward] [Conclusion] [Webinar Video] â€¢ 2021 Roundtable: On Islamic Legal Genres (convened by Necmettin Kizilkaya & Hakki Arslan), Islamic Law Blog (Dec. 2021) [Monthly Lecture Summaries] [Webinar Videos] â€¢ 2020 Roundtable: Islamic Legal History and Historiography (convened by Intisar Rabb & Mariam Sheibani), Islamic Law Blog (Dec. 2020â€“Feb. 2021) [Essays] [Webinar Video] â€¢ 2020 Special Roundtable on Covid 19: Pandemics in Islamic Law and History (convened by staff editors), Islamic Law Blog (May 2020) [Essays] â€¢ 2019 Roundtable: al-Muwaá¹­á¹­aÊ¾ by MÄlik b. name: Scholar Updates Roundup
description: A list of recent professional developments of scholars of Islamic law.

name: Scholarship in Plain English
description: A digest of accessible reviews of recent or well-known works of Islamic law scholarship on the most noteworthy questions and debates. In Plain English reviews serves as an entry point to the academic study of Islamic law, or light reading for those interested in the latest developments. For shorter summaries of individual concepts from the scholarship, see the Islamic Law Lexicon .

name: Weekly Roundups
description:
The Islamic Law Blog publishes weekly roundups to keep our followers abreast of the latest news, developments and scholarship relating to Islamic law.

To that end, we offer five weekly roundups:

(1) Islamic Law in the News Roundup: a summary of developments in Islamic law from across the globe.
(2) Weekend Scholarship Roundup: a list of newly-published scholarship on all subjects relating to Islamic law, ranging from books and articles to shorter opinion pieces and other audio-visual mediums.
(3) Islam and Data Science Roundup: a list of scholarship, surveys, statistical studies, and other material that employ data science on any matter pertaining to Islam and Islamic law.
(4) Field Guide to Islamic Law Online: a weekly list introducing two online resources of Islamic law, ranging from e-archives to e-libraries, from digitized personal collections to online depositories of first and secondary sources on Islamic law.
(5) COVID-19 and Islamic Law Roundup: a list of recent COVID-19-related developments in Muslim-majority countries and among Islamic communities.  Related to this particular roundup is our Mapping COVID-19 FatwÄs project, which compiles and discusses various Islamic legal opinions issued all across the globe on the pandemic and how Muslims ought to conduct themselves in the fight against it.

guest contributor expert commentary
description: Close analysis on issues of the day from a scholar weighing in on a particular issue. Contributors are either invited or send in one-time submissions that feature a close analysis of a single issue or publicationsâ€”including a new fatwÄ or case, research findings from a single study, or reviews of a new library or AI tool. All pieces pair content and context on Islamic law.

name: Guest editor expert commentary
description: Everything from reviews of recent publications and cases to reflections on the book-writing and tenure process for scholars in Islamic law. Junior and senior scholars known in the field of Islamic legal studies are invited to become guest editors of the blog for one-month terms. The posts do not undergo editorial review, and offer room for these scholars to content and context on Islamic law, and more.

student expert commentary
description: An incubator for Harvard student work on Islamic law throughout an academic term, under the supervision of Professor Intisar Rabb at Harvard Law School. Students spend a semester doing a dive deep into a subject of their choice based on new or historical cases, fatwÄs, or other sources of law. They place the content in context, sometimes with the assistance of machines. We post the results.
